DOD:S is a worthwhile purchase if you are into arcade-like WWII shooters.

DOD:S is a first-person game set in World War 2. It's a class-based shooter I should say much the same as the older GoldScr game. You can choose between the following classes:  -Rifler: Both the German and US soldiers possess a different rifle which is good for long and mid range combat. The German rifles kill in one shot, but are bolt-action, the US kill in two but are faster. Both also have rifle grenades,  -Assault: Has an smg - good for close range combat, apart from the usual explosive grenade also has a smoke one.  -Support: Has automatic rifles good for close and mid range combat, but still useful in long range, has a massive recoil you need to compensate for, but its pretty simple since it only goes up. Has a grenade.  -Sniper: Self-explanatory, good for long range, doesn't have x-rair when unscoped but can still be used in close range like a rifler would.   -Machine Gunner: Has a machine gun which can deployed with a bipod and used to defend flags and other objectives. If not deployed the MG has a GIGANTIC recoil.  -Rocket: Has a Rocket Launcher that mostly kills in 1 shot. Needs to be deployed to shoot, good for eliminating snipers.  Some classes are better all around than others but each have their uses. There are numerous official and custom maps and its a fun game. The problems is there aren't many players. Furthermore, quite a bit of servers have dumb rules and you may as well be kicked or banned.  I would recommend this game if it's on sale.

I do miss being able to play as the British from the HL1 mod, and a lot of the weapons are absent like the M1 carbine, the M3 grease gun, the FG 42, K43, Lee Enfield, and the Bren gun, and the Source version doesn't have quite as many maps from what I remember. I do like the alt-fire modes on many of the weapons, and the weapons feel nice and punchy like I remember, but compared to some more modern trappings, if you're looking for more realistic weapon behaviour and functionality like in Red Orchestra you may be left wanting.   Ultimately, it's still a fun nostalgic romp from a time where you'd be surprised at what you remember if you used to be a player, but you'll also be reminded why a lot of modern FPS innovations are taken for granted these days. Day of Defeat Source is an official sequel to Day of Defeat mod for Half-Life. It's a WW2 based multiplayer competive team-based FPS with classes. And aiming and headshots and dieing as you are peaking the corner from one bullet.  Multiplayer community is still alive. You will find at least few full servers that play same popular maps 24/7.  If to say about it short, then imagine Counter-Strike, but more balanced, with classes, more fun and without having to wait until the end of a round. In WW2 setting. And amazingly enough, it has interesting non-symmetrical maps, which is quite a rarity. Not sure if it's as balanced for both sides, but it makes it much more interesting to play with both teams. More team games should do this.  And yea, it has system where you lose energy if you sprint of jump, so if you plan on getting somewhere far away as fast as you can, just walk there, losing energy gives a huge temporary penalty on your speed. You also can run, walk, crouch or go prone, all will decide what kind of accuaricy you will have. Actually camping is a legit tactic there. But watch out, shootign gives you away, with all the muzzle fire effect and big light they give off, so don't expect to camp for too long, relocate. Or push. With teammates.  And it has two modes: 5 control points and detonation. Not much should be told about control points, though the last ones tend to be won by a sneaky person, tend to be too close to the enemy spawnpoint to really push with whole force. And I never got to play detonation maps, not popular enough, sorry.  So, what Source improved over original? Well, you guessed it, the most important change is the inclusion of ragdolls! Well, fine, not important, still nice. Graphics look more clean, less muddy.  They did some good work on class system, streamlining them and making them all more or less unique. In original, each side had 9 classes with seemingly random equipment, and there could be big difference between each side. In Source there are only 6 classes now, balanced and each made to have something that others don't have. Even better is that you can tell away what you are fighting against.  Anyway, let's get to it: - Rifleman are made for fighting at medium and far ranges. And short ranges. Can kill with a single bullet, but they don't shoot fast and their accuaricy is too lacking on the move. They are support to the main force, as well as sniping. Not going to do good at the very front of a force. They can now aim down iron sight, but seeing how they are accurate when standing and aiming down iron sight makes you crawl like turret, it's kinda useless. Can also shoot grenade out onto quite far distances.  - Assault classes are good only at close range and only if you are moving, otherwise you may use Support instead. Recoil and accuaricy losses on his main gun is minimal, it's just that it's not accurate to begin with. Has grenades. And importanly, has smoke grenades, that he can either use for himself, to get into smoke and use his close-range gun at advantage. Or he can use it to team, for tactics, like covering place which is dominated by enemy machine gunners.  - Support class is actually the main class around there. His automatic gun is kinda average, for medium ranges. Have to learn to aim with this one. Can shoot one bullet at a time in alternative mode. Also has grenades. Has pistol.  - Snipers are like rifleman but with sniping scope that makes them accurate. But without grenade-shooting. No, you still don't camp, machine gunners do better job than you. And rifleman do better job at you. You should be at far away but still moving and starfing a lot. Switching to scope mode is instant and accurate fully even when you are standing, so use it to full advantage.  - Machine gunners are the people who defend and clean streets and open spaces until there is nothing left inside. Can defend rooms too, but that asks for a nade. And can do better job than camping snipers. They really kill anything at any range, you have to know where they are and to come out from unexpected angle. Good thing there is a limit on them. You have to go prone to set up machine gun, but you can use any ledge you find as well. At least they can't shoot much while undeployed at least, the recoil and accuaricy loss are gigantic. There are however some players who use while travelling through small rooms, when you can just 'shotgun' anybody, having learnt to compensate recoil. But at least there arent many of such players. Also have pistols.  - Rocket class has rocket launcher and autoatic little weapons. In original they were just there to have 'random' selection to troll you, being useless, only there to blow some objectives in very few maps, I heard. In Source, the explosion of bazooka was buffed up, having bigger radius. It's actually good at taking out machine gunner spots. Some of them. the thing is, you have to put them over shoulder to shoot and that makes you crawl, so it's still kinda weird support class. But hey, at least they have automatic gun as backup weapon, not pistol. Those are actually good. So yay source!  So yea. Still addictive, still campish. Still good. Or better. It's more streamlined and feels more sane in balance for sure.
